poem:
Title: "Under Paris, A Shark Presides"

In the catacombs of my morning coffee,
a mobile, gray shape of fear and fascination,
the black and white of newspaper print
transform into the clicks and clacks of claustrophobia.
A Parisian labyrinth leagues under,
there lies an aquatic terror, yet distinctly human.
The heart monitor beeps timed with suspense,
oh, the grandeur of our celluloid dread
unfolding beneath the breakfast toast.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Under Paris: Netflix has delivered one of the best shark movies ever made Almost exactly a decade ago, I unwittingly played into an extremely corny publicity gimmick by wearing a heart-rate monitor during a movie screening. I did this because the film in question was supposedly one of the scariest ever made. I would wear the monitor, and my involuntary responses would provide everyone with quantifiable proof of just how scary it was. But it". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
